physical_appearance: The image shows several items such as a black-and-white photograph, a yellow bottle containing oil, a rectangular packaging, and a leaflet. Three people can be seen posing in the photograph. There are Chinese characters on the packaging, and the image of a Tiger is displayed on it as well. The yellow label wrapped around the bottle contains the 'formula' showing the different percentages of its components. The leaflet contains the images of two business personnel at the top. The image shows several items such as a black-and-white photograph, a yellow bottle containing oil, a rectangular packaging, and a leaflet. Three people can be seen posing in the photograph. There are Chinese characters on the packaging, and the image of a Tiger is displayed on it as well. The yellow label wrapped around the bottle contains the 'formula' showing the different percentages of its components. The leaflet contains the images of two business personnel at the top.
sgcool_label_text:
The Tiger balm brand remains today an important local brand and traces its history back to the Aw brothers—Au Boon Haw and Aw Boon Par. Their father, Au Chu Kin was an herbalist who started Eng Aun Tong (the Hall of Everlasting Peace) and passed the product formula to his sons in the early 1900s.  The Aw brothers perfected the formula in oil and balm form.  The oil form was the original form and was popular in Singapore households from the 1930s onwards.
The photograph depicts three visitors to the Tiger Balm gardens (also known as the Haw Par Villa). This villa garden was an entertainment park to teach and preserve traditional Chinese values (such as filial piety) through the exposition of folklore, legends and historical events in the form of tableaux and figurines.
